pr_title: Password management: Allow an authenticated user to reset password

timeline.message: Allow an authenticated user to renew his password by disabling the sso on the flow.
Allow an authenticated user to renew his password by disabling the sso on the flow.
Only use the PM SSO Strategy when you're trying to reset the password
Add unit tests for the PM SSO Strategy.
Add unit tests for the PM SSO Strategy.
Add unit tests for the PM SSO Strategy.

timeline.bodyText:
I think this is a good starting point as a check. Is there something else, in addition to the request parameter check, that can be done to detect the request as a password-reset? Perhaps something in the RequestContext that track this execution as "this is a password reset"?
For example, a password-reset request should be:

There is a token in the request
It's valid token, has not been used, has not expired, etc.
Only then, when all those checks pass should SSO be disabled.

I suspect those checks are already part of the flow, (you should not have to repeat them here) and their result is tracked in RequestContext, or should be if not already.
There is no danger in this solution per se; I'd like to see if there is a way we could harden the check, and not allow bypassing of SSO only with a simple request parameter (that anyone any way can supply with any value).
timeline.author: mmoayyed

Yes, VerifyPasswordResetRequestAction is probably the best spot. It should be tracking the result of the token validation, or if not, you could add something to the request context that tracks that, and then use that in the strategy for disabling sso.
The trick is to make sure that action and its result are executed and tracked before the sso strategy runs, so the result can be used. If they run after, then we can possibly add logic in the strategy again to validate the token similar to how the action runs those validation rules.

Both of those snippets do the same thing; perhaps one fails if the token is not found?


You should not check if the token is a TST. You should just check that the token can be found, and can be parsed. Ignore its type.


If it's not valid, then you should not disable SSO and should continue to support the request. But, if the token is not valid, some of the other actions that verify the token should fail. Failing is the correct behavior.

replies.bodyText:
OK, so that's where another problem lies. This is what should happen:
When a token is specified even with SSO, some webflow action must run to validate the token. If token is valid, the flow proceeds. If the token is invalid, then the flow should stop and must route to an error page, explaining the scenario. It sounds like this validation step is missing in the flow when there is SSO, so perhaps a new action needs to be added at the very beginning of the flow in the right stop to make sure if a valid token is specified for password resets.
Once you have this action in place, then the SSO strategy can do its job as it does now; validate the token and determine SSO etc.
I can take a look at the webflow validation action and try to fix it if it's easier for you to resume your work here.

timeline.message: The PM SSO Strategy will be used only if the request contain a password reset token which exists in the registry.

timeline.bodyText: You should be using CentralAuthenticationService, and then catch exceptions when you get the ticket. Also, please add logging statements under debug/trace to the method here to explain the behavior.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText:
Will do it. :)
I'm a bit curious. Is it related to performance to catch an exception rather than have a null response ?
replies.author: julienhuon

replies.bodyText: No, it has to do with transactional semantics. Fetching a ticket id via TicketRegistry without a running transaction can cause issues for registry implementations that require transactions like those backed by JDBC and a relational database. CentralAuthenticationService helps with that.
